comments.commentBody:
Fact boy: Positrons are generated inside the nuclei of very real atoms in a process called "positron emission." Both electrons and positrons can be formed by the decay of radioactive nuclei. So, a better clue would be "source of positrons," since they don't "live" in the nuclei for long. Also, ATOM is a bit broad for the answer, but a nucleus is part of an atom.

I thought this was a very clever construction, fitting in four long theme answers containing MAN and the revealer. The clever construction did lead, however, to some less wonderful answers and a very easy solve.

No, they're losing in large part because of Obama and trying to do damage control: the senators most in danger of losing their jobs have been strong supporters of the president in Congress.  I believe Pryor, for example, has cast votes supporting Obama's policies over 90% of the time: that isn't playing well in Arkansas.
His party is "benching" him?  Well maybe that's why they're fixing to lose the Senate this time.

Sure, if we are operating at the limit of attainable efficiency, getting more tangible goods requires using more energy. We are not anywhere near the fundamental limits in most cases.

40 years ago, I worked to automate cement plants in the US and in Europe. European plants made the same quantity of cement with better quality using 1/2 the energy compared to US plants. Construction costs were essentially identical. Why the difference: European energy costs were far higher, so the designers were more sensitive to energy use. There was additional design effort required for the more efficient plants--but this had a negligible cost on the plants or the product.

California has required more efficient appliances since 1977 saving upwards of 74 billion dollars for consumers (at negligible per appliance cost). Attention to design gets results.

The typical human in the US and the planet could command a much better standard of living than today with the same overall energy and resource budget-if we want this outcome. Fostering "winner take all" contests of conspicuous waste (what the economics rules in play seem to encourage) will likely continue to waste resources, further degrading the global environment.

I would be interested in seeing what the least invasive changes to the "rules of the economic game" might be to allow improving economic product without degrading the planet.

As a pediatrician, I give hundreds of shots each month.  I found a tip many years ago describing the use of a LaMaze technique for decreasing pain to be very helpful for kids about 4 years and up.  I ask the child to visualize a make believe balloon in their favorite color and to blow it up slowly with their eyes closed and watch it expand.  The injection takes place during this time of concentration and many times the kids report less or no discomfort.  Some of the patients like it so much they use the technique when they have to give blood or undergo other painful procedures.

I forced my now 7 yo to keep a journal over the summer for the past two years in order to practice writing.  His delight upon discovering that he ate the same flavour of ice cream (cotton candy) on the same day two years in a row makes me think that these researchers are on to something.

A woman can be healthy after being raped but we don't say then that the rape didn't matter. Simply healthy mother and baby is too low a standard. If that is the standard then anything can happen in the hospital and so long as she's not permanently disabled, it's okay? The mother must be respected such that she is cut only with sound medical reasons (not liability concerns or provider convenience). With a third of pregnancies ending in sections these days, many women are being disrespected. And we are only beginning to appreciate the long term sequelae of these unnecessary surgeries, from lifelong abdominal adhesions to altered gut bacteria in the child. It DOES matter.

take not counsel of your fears...or, judging by the post, of your desires.

Truth be told, no one knows how this ebola epidemic will transpire. Anybody who says that they do, is not to be entirely believed.
The one crucial element not discussed too broadly is that the ebola virus can be spread via sexual contact. This in itself is a horrific thought.
How is that aspect going to be contained and not spread ebola like wild fire?
And viral mutations can happen, very quickly. What's true about ebola today may not be the same tomorrow. Virologists are bracing for unknown variants of this very unpredictable and lethal disease. Can our pharmacology/pathology keep up with an ever changing or morphing virus? Highly doubtful.

Remember that Republican legislator in Ohio, I think it was Ohio, bragging that the state government passed Voter ID and it would mean Romney would win Ohio?  He actually said it on camera.  The claim of voter fraud as the reason for these laws is a fraud.
And a legislator in Pennsylvania, where the Voter ID law was overturned by the state courts, also said that passing Voter ID would ensure Romney's election.

Vklip - think about it, you can interpret your comment several different ways depending on who you would have voted for.

http://www.nhregister.com/government-and-politics/20140926/bridgeport-st...

I don't know if having a mandatory state/federal ID law or changes to when an individual can vote, would make the integrity of the voting system more secure. I do know that voter fraud does happen - maybe just a few times or maybe more than a few times. However, something as important and as integral to our democracy as our right to vote should always be above any suspicion of impropriety. We have "airtight" rules, laws and identification for any manner of things far less important than voting.

http://www.nhregister.com/government-and-politics/20140926/bridgeport-st...
Unfortunately, Roberts, Scalia, Kennedy, Thomas and Alito are watching this charade smugly and quite happily.

It's not always the GOP. North Carolina's Republican-led legislature has reduced early voting hours, but traditionally Democrat states such as New York, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Connecticut, New Hampshire, Maine, Delaware, Michigan and Minnesota disallow early voting altogether.

“I don’t believe that any of these judges are deciding cases because they want to help, in quotes, their party win the election,” Mr. Hasen said.

He's wrong, clearly

I spent some of my American childhood in Hong Kong under the British Flag. Even back then (1949) the native Chinese strongly identified with their city. Yes, Mainland has discouraged the people of Hong Kong but just for the moment for in the fullness of time the mainland strangle-hold will become weak and Hong Kong will remain eternally free. Her people are deeply loyal to Hong Kong.
I experienced this with my own eyes.
@ht tsan:  Please provide a link.

Wow ... I think the analogy is going a bit out of hand. I am no fun of the Chinese government, but we are not talking about the Chinese government sending soldiers to "rape, burn and pillage to bring back" the HKer to Motherland. I am afraid you let your imagination carried yourself too far. In fact, the Chinese government has been very liberal toward HK by all standards - the city can set its own education/welfare/public security policies. Almost everything goes except military and diplomatic controls. 15th century is a long time ago. Let's stay what it is today, shall we?
I am Chinese, and in Canada now. I agree with you. I witnessed what Chinese government has brought to Hongkong since 1997.

Hong Kong and these attitudes of belonging to the city NEAR CHina, not to a city IN china, are reminiscent of the Low Countries of what was known as Spanish Netherlands. In the mid 15th century, they were the technical, scientific, business center of Europe. Painting, Woolcraft, clockwork, machines, optics- high tech of the time were part-and heart of these tiny city states borfered by the North Sea, France and German principalities.
They were religiously ever more, protestant and the Inqusititions,(there were at lest 4 separate Inquisitions: Papal, State, Spanish and , at least one or two others.), wereantsy that these deutch-men were getting too "uppity"-Then Charles V relinquished "Empire" to become a monk-his son, Phil II, sent soldiers (through France!!!), ( Protestant soldiers, by the way) to rape, burn and pillage to bring back the dutch to the Church. As a result, war raged over the Netherlandish and Belgic city-states for another century before Catholics separated from Protestants.There was a similar pride of being born in certain cities as their "birth registered" residents as there is in Hong Kong among those born and resident there..Hong Kongers sound exactly like these Dutch-. "With, but not of, Charle's holy Roman Catholic empire, but more proud of being Dutch. Charles understood. Philip hated and despised, as heresy. Eliz I , siren like, beckoned from across the channel them : come to Angleterre-be free . . .

“There’s growing angst about Turkey dragging its feet to act to prevent a massacre less than a mile from its border,” a senior administration official said. “After all the fulminating about Syria’s humanitarian catastrophe, they’re inventing reasons not to act to avoid another catastrophe.

“This isn’t how a NATO ally acts while hell is unfolding a stone’s throw from their border,” said the official, who spoke anonymously to avoid publicly criticizing an ally."

Angst?

Around the world leaders know Obama, if punked, will perhaps scold, then punch a hippie. Good times with the U.S. jv.

The WH doesn't have time for a policy. It must prepare For the next time Erdogan publicly punks the U.S. And demands an apology. He was gracious though. He did not demand Biden kiss his feet. Maybe next time.

Putin sneers, steals some more Estonians. Life is good.

Sleep sound. The WH has angst, which is a substitute not for just a policy but for more than two bombing sorties a day on 9,000 with heavy artillery. You know there is not a military solution for every problem. There is angst too.

As a scientist, I'll have to go with Dr. Krugman on this one. I wasn't impressed by the Buchanan essay. The essay does nothing to establish whether energy efficiency improvements are potentially very large, or not so large. Without that, the argument rests on the historical relation between energy use and output. But that relationship is not necessary relevant because energy has been so cheap - so of course energy use has tended to remain quite high. Furthermore it is far from clear that energy production is reaching its limits, since the potential of solar energy is so large.

Of course, mathematical arguments based on exponential growth are correct in principle - eventually the exponential will win out over any other factor. But we're not talking about the t -> infinity limit here. On the time scale of the next few decades, the "infinite exponential" is irrelevant.

IMO the potential for increased energy efficiency and solar energy is very large, and the economy is going to continue to grow at a modest rate for at least the next several decades, even if significant limitations on fossil fuels are enacted.
